thread.title: Hollywood golden age ingénue Joan Leslie dies at 90
thread.title_full: Hollywood golden age ingénue Joan Leslie dies at 90 - Times Union

author: timesunion.com
title: Hollywood golden age ingénue Joan Leslie dies at 90
text:
Photo: Matt Sayles, AP Image 1 of / 2 2 FILE - In this Aug. 12, 2006 file photo, actress Joan Leslie poses for photographers at the Golden Boot Awards in Beverly Hills, Calif. Leslie, whose expressive almond eyes and innocent beauty made her one of the most popular film ingenues of the 1930s and 40s, has died at the age of 90. She died in Los Angeles on Monday, Oct. 12, 2015, her family announced in an obituary. FILE - In this Aug. 12, 2006 file photo, actress Joan Leslie poses for photographers at the Golden Boot Awards in Beverly Hills, Calif. Leslie, whose expressive almond eyes and innocent beauty made her one ... more Photo: Matt Sayles, AP Image 2 of 2 FILE - In this May 14, 1998 file photo, Joan Leslie stands near the movie poster for Irving Berlin's "This is the Army" in which Leslie starred with Ronald Reagan, at the museum on the Warner Bros. lot during a tour marking the film studio's 75th anniversary in Burbank, Calif. Leslie, whose expressive almond eyes and innocent beauty made her one of the most popular film ingenues of the 1930s and 40s, has died at the age of 90. She died in Los Angeles on Monday, Oct. 12, 2015, her family announced in an obituary. FILE - In this May 14, 1998 file photo, Joan Leslie stands near the movie poster for Irving Berlin's "This is the Army" in which Leslie starred with Ronald Reagan, at the museum on the Warner Bros. lot ... more Photo: Susan Sterner, AP Hollywood golden age ingénue Joan Leslie dies at 90 1 / 2 Back to Gallery LOS ANGELES (AP) — Joan Leslie , whose expressive almond eyes and innocent beauty made her one of the most popular film ingénues of the 1930s and 40s, has died at the age of 90.
She died in Los Angeles on Monday, her family announced in an obituary.
After signing with Warner Bros. at the age of 15, her first major role was in "High Sierra" as the disabled Velma opposite Humphrey Bogart and Ida Lupino.
In her 20-year career, the Detroit native performed in over 30 films. She romanced Gary Cooper in "Sergeant York," danced with Fred Astaire in "The Sky's the Limit," and sang with James Cagney in "Yankee Doodle Dandy."
After marrying physician William Caldwell in 1950, she put her career on hold to raise her twin daughters and do charity.
